statement:
Let $F/K$ be an extension of number fields such that for any
intermediate Galois extension $L/K$, with $K\subsetneq L \subsetneq F$,
there is at least one finite place or infinite place which ramifies in
the extension $L/K$. Then, $h_K$, the class number of $K$, divides the
class number of $F$, $h_F$.

First, we deduce some immediate corollaries.

Let $F/K$ be an extension of number fields which is totally ramified at
some prime (or at an archimedean place). Then $h_K$ divides $h_F$.

The proof is clear since there cannot be unramified subextensions. The
theorem applies.

Let $F/K$ be a Galois extension of number fields such that
${\operatorname{Gal}}(F/K)$ is a non-abelian simple group. Then $h_K$
divides $h_F$.

In this case, there cannot be subextensions with abelian Galois group
and the theorem applies.

Let $H$ be the Hilbert class field of $K$. By definition, $H$ is the
maximal unramified abelian extension of $K$, ${\operatorname{Gal}}(H/K)$
is isomorphic to ${\operatorname{Cl}}(K)$, the ideal class group of $K$
and $[H:K]=h_K$. Since there are no nontrivial unramified abelian
subextensions of $F/K$, we have $F\cap H=K$ and so $[FH:F]=[H:K]=h_K$.
One can show that the extension $FH/F$ is unramified and abelian (in
fact ${\operatorname{Gal}}(FH/F)\cong {\operatorname{Gal}}(H/K)$).
Therefore $FH$ is contained in $L$, the Hilbert class field of $F$.
Hence: $$h_F=[L:F]=[L:FH]\cdot[FH:F]=[L:FH]\cdot [H:K]=[L:FH]\cdot h_K$$
and so, $h_K$ divides $h_F$.
names: extensions without unramified subextensions and class number divisibility
